Canada spends [$72.2 Billion](https://www.fin.gc.ca/tax-impot/2014/html-eng.asp) last year on "transfers to persons", which includes EI, old age security, guaranteed income supplements, children's benefits, and allowances for spouses. Digging around a little more, you can find an extra [$3 Billion](https://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/inpr/afhoce/afhoce_021.cfm) annually in social housing funding.
That's for a total of $75.7 Billion. Assuming you completely eliminated all of those things, you could provide a universal basic income of $2080 annually to every Canadian, or about $173 a month. You might be able to push it a little higher if you wanted to exclude children as well but I wouldn't do that. So not exactly an encouraging number.
